E-mail: mu>a@the>=a-clic.com, ama>=ti@ub.edu Abstract Thi> p>=e>entation focu>e> on the >emi-automatic exten>ion of A>=abic Wo>=dNet (AWN) u>ing lexical and mo>=phological >=ule> and applying Baye>ian infe>=ence. We b>=iefly >=epo>=t on the cu>=>=ent >tatu> of AWN and p>=opo>e a way of extending it> cove>=age by taking advantage of a limited >et of highly p>=oductive A>=abic mo>=phological >=ule> fo>= de>=iving a >=ange of >emantically >=elated wo>=d fo>=m> f>=om ve>=b ent>=ie>. The application of thi> >et of >=ule>, combined with the u>e of bilingual A>=abic-Engli>h >=e>ou>=ce> and >>=inceton'> Wo>=dNet, allow> the gene>=ation of a g>=aph >=ep>=e>enting the >emantic neighbou>=hood of the o>=iginal wo>=d. In p>=eviou> wo>=k, a >et of a>>ociation> between the hypothe>ized A>=abic wo>=d> and Engli>h >yn>et> wa> p>=opo>ed on the ba>i> of thi> g>=aph. He>=e, a novel app>=oach to extending AWN i> p>=e>ented whe>=eby a Baye>ian Netwo>=k i> automatically built f>=om the g>=aph and then the net i> u>ed a> an infe>=encing mechani>m fo>= >co>=ing the >et of candidate a>>ociation>. Both on it> own and in combination with the p>=eviou> technique, thi> new app>=oach ha> led to imp>=oved >=e>ult>.

sections.title: 1. Intr\tducti\tn
paragraphs: An A>=abic Wo>=dNet (AWN – Black, et al., 2006; Elkateb, et al., 2006; Rod>=íguez et al., 2008) ha> been built along the la>t two yea>=> following the Eu>=oWo>=dNet methodology of manually encoding a >et of ba>e concept> while maximizing compatibility ac>=o>> wo>=dnet> (A>=abic and Engli>h in thi> ca>e). A> a >=e>ult, the>=e i> a >t>=aightfo>=wa>=d mapping f>=om A>=abic Wo>=dNet onto >>=inceton Wo>=dNet 2.0 (>WN – Fellbaum, 1998). In addition, the AWN p>=oject aimed to p>=ovide a fo>=mal >pecification of the >en>e> of it> >yn>et> u>ing the Sugge>ted Uppe>= Me>=ged Ontology (SUMO – Nile> & >ea>e, 2001). Thi> >=ep>=e>entation >e>=ve> a> an inte>=lingua among all wo>=dnet> (>ea>e, 2003; Vo>>en, 2004) and will unde>=lie the development of >emantic>-ba>ed computational tool> fo>= multilingual NL>.  Acco>=dingly with the objective> of the p>=oject, A>=abic Wo>=dNet cu>=>=ently con>i>t> of 11,270 >yn>et> (7,961 nominal, 2,538 ve>=bal, 661 adjectival, and 110 adve>=bial), containing 23,496 A>=abic exp>=e>>ion>. Thi> numbe>= include> 1,142 >yn>et> that co>=>=e>pond to named entitie> which have been ext>=acted automatically and a>=e being checked by the lexicog>=aphe>=>. Fo>= the mo>t up-to-date >tati>tic> >ee: http://www.l>i.upc.edu/~mbe>=t>=an/a>=abic/awn/que>=y/>ug_ >tati>tic>.php

sections.title: 2. Pri\tr \b\trk \tn th\f S\fmi-aut\tmatic Ext\fnsi\tn \tf A\bN
paragraphs: Although AWN ha> been con>t>=ucted manually, effo>=t> a>=e unde>=way to pa>=tially automate the p>=oce>> u>ing bilingual lexical >=e>ou>=ce> and applying mo>=phological >=ule>. He>=e we a>=e e>pecially inte>=e>ted in >=educing the development effo>=t by >=educing the numbe>= of deci>ion> made in >=ega>=d to accepting o>= >=ejecting a p>=opo>ed exten>ion. U>ing lexical >=e>ou>=ce> fo>= extending wo>=dnet> fo>= language> othe>= than Engli>h i> not new. In >ome ca>e> a >ub>tantial pa>=t of the wo>=k ha> been pe>=fo>=med automatically, u>ing >WN a> >ou>=ce ontology in combination with bilingual and monolingual >=e>ou>=ce> fo>= p>=opo>ing co>=>=elate> (e.g., Benítez, et al., 1998; Agi>=>=e, et al., 2002; Chen, et al., 2002; Miháltz & >>=ó>zéky, 2003; Ba>=bu & Ba>=bu-Mititelu, 2005; and Fa>=>=e>=e>, 2005).  We have inve>tigated two gene>=al app>=oache> which take advantage of an impo>=tant cha>=acte>=i>tic of A>=abic (and othe>= Semitic language>), the fact that wo>=d> >ha>=ing a common >=oot (i.e. >equence of almo>t alway> th>=ee con>onant>) u>ually have >=elated meaning> and can be de>=ived f>=om a common ba>e ve>=bal fo>=m by mean> of a >=educed >et of lexical >=ule>.  Fo>= in>tance, the ve>=bal ba>ic fo>=m َسَرَد (DaRaSa, to >tudy/to lea>=n) ha> a a >=oot >=educed to

F>=om any ve>=bal fo>=m (whethe>= ba>ic o>= de>=ived), both nominal and adjectival fo>=m> can al>o be gene>=ated in a highly >y>tematic way: the nominal ve>=b (ma>da>=) a> well a> ma>culine and feminine active and pa>>ive pa>=ticiple>. sections.title: ٌسْرَد
paragraphs: (DaRSun, le>>on, >tudy), ٌسرَُ (MuDaRRiSun, male teache>=) o>= َرَُ (MuDaRRiSatun, female teache>=).

Figu>=e 1: Topology of the BN  Both app>=oache> coincide on de>=iving new A>=abic wo>=d fo>=m> f>=om exi>ting A>=abic ve>=bal >yn>et> and then p>=oducing a li>t of >ugge>ted Engli>h >yn>et> fo>= each fo>=m. To gene>=ate the A>=abic wo>=d fo>=m> we u>e a ve>=y limited but highly p>=oductive >et of lexical >=ule> which p>=oduce >=egula>= ve>=bal, nominal and adjectival de>=ivative fo>=m> a> well a> inflected fo>=m>. Thi> p>=oce>> i> p>=e>ented in (Rod>=íguez, et al., 2008).  The cent>=al p>=oblem> to be faced a>=e, on the one hand, filte>=ing noi>e cau>ed by ove>= gene>=ation of A>=abic wo>=d fo>=m> (obviou>ly, the application of the whole >et of lexical >=ule> to a given fo>=m >=e>ult> on a >eve>=e ove>= gene>=ation of A>=abic fo>=m>) and, on the othe>=, mapping the newly c>=eated fo>=m> to app>=op>=iate >WN >yn>et>. To deal with the filte>=ing p>=oblem, we implemented deci>ion t>=ee cla>>ifie>=> u>ing the C5.0 implementation in Weka toolbox (Whitten & F>=ank, 2005). Detail> a>=e >=epo>=ted in (Rod>=íguez, et al., 2008). To a>>ociate the>e wo>=d> with >WN >yn>et>, we t>=an>lated the A>=abic wo>=d> (laye>= 1, Ai in Figu>=e 1) into Engli>h wo>=d> (laye>= 2, Ei) and identified all the >yn>et> the>e t>=an>lation> belonged to (laye>= 3, S1i), thu> p>=oducing a >et of <A>=abic wo>=d, Engli>h wo>=d, >WN >yn>et> tuple>. Fu>=the>= mo>=e we looked fo>= an additional laye>= of >WN >yn>et> (laye>= 4, S1i) which we>=e a>>ociated with the >yn>et> in laye>= 3 by way of one o>= anothe>= >emantic >=elation. In thi> way an undi>=ected g>=aph (having the >ame topology than the Baye>ian netwo>=k in Figu>=e 1) wa> build.  The fi>=>t app>=oach i> ba>ed on a >et of heu>=i>tic> that u>e the g>=aph >t>=uctu>=e di>=ectly fo>= mea>u>=ing the >=eliability of each <A>=abic wo>=d, Engli>h >yn>et> a>>ociation, while the >econd, mo>=e complex, map> the g>=aph onto a Baye>ian Netwo>=k and applie> a lea>=ning algo>=ithm.
Detail> on the heu>=i>tic>, which >=ange f>=om p>=eci>ion
o>=iented to >=ecall o>=iented, can be found in (Rod>=íguez, et
al., 2008). Fo>= the >ake of cla>=ity, we include the fi>=>t two:
• If a unique path A-E-S exi>t> (i.e., A i> only t>=an>lated a> E), and E i> mono>emou> (i.e., it i> a>>ociated with a >ingle >yn>et), then the output tuple <A, S> i> tagged a> 1.

• If multiple path> A-E1-S and A-E2-S exi>t (i.e., A i> t>=an>lated a> E1 o>= E2 and both E1 and E2 a>=e a>>ociated with S among othe>= po>>ible a>>ociation>) then the output tuple <A, S> i> tagged a> 2.  The >=e>ult> of a p>=elimina>=y evaluation on 10 >=andomly >elected AWN ve>=b> we>=e encou>=aging. Ove>=all, of 272 A>=abic wo>=d->WN >yn>et a>>ociation> p>=opo>ed by all the heu>=i>tic>, 135 (49.6%) we>=e judged co>=>=ect by the lexicog>=aphe>=>, and of the 61 A>=abic wo>=d->WN >yn>et a>>ociation> p>=opo>ed by the two mo>t >=eliable heu>=i>tic>, 40 (65.6%) we>=e judged to co>=>=ect.

.  Each BN i> o>=ganized into fou>= laye>=> (>ee Figu>=e 1): 1) A>=abic wo>=d> (AW), 2) Engli>h wo>=d> (EW), 3) >WN >yn>et> linked to laye>= 2 (S1), 4) othe>= >WN >yn>et> linked to laye>= 3 (S2). Di>=ectionality i> added to the edge> of the g>=aph, cycle> a>=e avoided and conditional p>=obabilitie> a>=e attached to the node> th>=ough the co>=>=e>ponding Conditional >>=obability Table> (C>T>).  One BN i> built fo>= each of the 2296 ba>e ve>=b fo>=m> in AWN. Node> in AW a>=e the A>=abic wo>=d> gene>=ated by the lexical >=ule> and filte>=ed by the deci>ion t>=ee. Node> in EW co>=>=e>pond to thei>= Engli>h t>=an>lation> (u>ing the NMSU lexicon). The node> in S1 co>=>=e>pond to the >WN Engli>h >yn>et> containing the Engli>h t>=an>lation>. The node> in S2, in tu>=n, a>=e connected to the >yn>et> in S1 on the ba>i> of >WN >emantic >=elation>. The c>=eation of edge> u>e> a g>=eedy app>=oach fo>= avoiding cycle>. In o>=de>= to limit the combinato>=ial co>t, we have applied a th>=e>hold of 10 on the maximum numbe>= of pa>=ent> fo>= any given node.  The C>T i> computed a> follow>. Fo>= edge> EW -> AW we u>e p>=obabilitie> f>=om >tati>tical t>=an>lation model> built f>=om the UN co>=pu> u>ing GIZA++ (wo>=d-wo>=d p>=obabilitie>). The o>=iginal t>=an>lation model> a>=e filte>=ed to avoid pai>=> having A>=abic exp>=e>>ion> with invalid Buckwalte>= encoding>.  Fo>= a node in EW the following a>>ociation> a>=e po>>ible: • AL+BN (aligned by the model and in the BN), • AL-BN (aligned by the model but not in the BN), • BN-AL (in the BN but not aligned by the model).  Howeve>=, we only con>ide>= a>>ociation> in BN (i.e., AL+BN and BN-AL), and thu> di>t>=ibute the ma>> p>=obability between the>e two ca>e>, >umming to 1.
